article.description:
Rashad Anderson scored 17 points and Hilton
Armstrong had a career-high five blocked shots as Connecticut (No. 6 ESPN/USA Today, No. 7 AP) 
cruised to a 99-48 victory over Florida International on Tuesday
night.
article.headline: FIU couldn't compete with UConn frontline
article.linkText: School-record 19 blocks sets pace for UConn
article.story:
STORRS, Conn. (AP) -- Connecticut jumped all over Florida
International on Tuesday night but not nearly fast enough for coach
Jim Calhoun.

	   Calhoun called a timeout just 9 seconds into the game right
after the Golden Panthers grabbed the opening tip and scored on a
thunderous dunk by Byron Burnett.

	   "I was upset we didn't jump on them right away," Calhoun said.
"You don't want anybody to hang around and feel good about
themselves."

	   The Huskies (No. 6 ESPN/USA Today, No. 7 AP) 
 heard Calhoun loud and clear and
didn't let up for the rest of the night, cruising to a 99-48 win.

	   Rashad Anderson scored 17 points and Hilton Armstrong had a
career-high five blocked shots for UConn.

	   Armstrong and Josh Boone, who had four blocked shots and 11
rebounds, were part of UConn's dominating frontcourt that recorded
a school-record 19 blocks. The Huskies (2-0) outrebounded FIU
57-36.

	   "After 5 or 6 minutes, we just took the starch out of them and
just pounded the ball inside," Calhoun said.

	   When FIU switched to a zone defense, UConn had plenty of offense
from the perimeter as well, going 9-of-19 from 3-point range.

	   Ivan Almonte and Ishmael N'Diaye led the Golden Panthers (3-2)
with 12 points each. FIU, on a two-game swing in the state, was
coming off its first road win in 16 straight games, beating Central
Connecticut 63-61 on Sunday. The Panthers were no match for the
defending NCAA champs.

	   The bigger, faster Huskies got to the foul line 30 times, making
20.

	   "We're not going to fool ourselves. We came in here trying to
get a split and we did," FIU coach Sergio Rouco said. "The good
thing is our kids came out of it as a group. I've got real tight
group. There were no excuses. They were better than us."

	   UConn was coming off a weeklong exhibition tour in London where
freshman Rudy Gay emerged as a solid performer, averaging 15.5
points and 6.5 rebounds. He scored 12 points against the Golden
Panthers and had eight rebounds and three blocks.

	   "We had more talent, we had more size and we were able to
impose that," Calhoun said. "Every time you went up inside for a
shot it was contested."

	   UConn fired up eight 3-pointers in the first half, mostly in
transition, to run away with the game. Denham Brown led the way
going 3-of-4 from behind the arc. He twisted his right ankle on his
final shot and had to leave the game for good. He finished with 13
points, all in the first half.

	   UConn shot 52.5 percent in the half in taking a 55-23 lead.

	   The Huskies returned home from London on Sunday and by game time
Tuesday, most said jet lag wasn't a factor.

	   "Maybe on that first play, but other than that I don't think
there was too much jet lag involved," Boone said. "The time in
London was good because it let us play against grown men and pro
teams. But in the end we're going to have to play against college
teams."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
